subject: Re: [junit] Making JUnit more pluggable for add-ons
msgSnippet: ... If the decorator (Tp) does not require external configuration, then I d vote for a property-based factory as implied by the first option.  If profiling is
messageBody:
Michael Silverstein wrote:

> This brings up a question that I've been pondering: Given a test T, which of
> the following two choices is more desirable?
> o Enable profiling for T by specifying some preference and let the
> execution framework do the rest.
> o Enable profiling for T by coding a new test Tp that decorates T with
> profiling. When you want to run T with profiling you run Tp. When you want
> to run T without it you just run T. This is very similar to the way
> JUnitPerf works.

If the decorator (Tp) does not require external configuration, then I'd vote for
a property-based factory as implied by the first option. If profiling is
enabled, then the factory manufactures Tp instances, otherwise it manufactures T
instances.

If, however, the decorator does requires configuration above and beyond the test
instance it decorates, as is the case for JUnitPerf, then the second option
seems to work better. The specific test instances may still be manufactured by
a factory, but configuration-related information must be supplied independent of
the execution framework.

Mike
